subtopics.title: Introduction to Coordinate Geometry
subtopics.content:
Introduction

Coordinate Geometry helps us locate points and analyze shapes using numbers (coordinates).

subtopics.title: Cartesian Plane
subtopics.content:
Cartesian Plane

Formed by two perpendicular lines:

  • x-axis (horizontal)
  • y-axis (vertical)

Intersection point → Origin (0,0).

subtopics.title: Coordinates of a Point
subtopics.content:
Coordinates of a Point

Each point is represented as (x, y).

x = abscissa (distance from y-axis), y = ordinate (distance from x-axis).

Example: (3, –2) means 3 units right, 2 units down.

subtopics.title: Quadrants
subtopics.content:
Quadrants

Divided into 4 regions:

  • Quadrant I → (+, +)
  • Quadrant II → (–, +)
  • Quadrant III → (–, –)
  • Quadrant IV → (+, –)

subtopics.title: Distance Formula
subtopics.content:
Distance Formula

Distance between (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):

d = √[(x₂ – x₁)² + (y₂ – y₁)²]

subtopics.title: Midpoint Formula
subtopics.content:
Midpoint Formula

Midpoint of (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):

((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)

subtopics.title: Section Formula
subtopics.content:
Section Formula

If P(x, y) divides the line joining (x₁, y₁) & (x₂, y₂) in ratio m:n:

P = ((mx₂ + nx₁)/(m+n), (my₂ + ny₁)/(m+n))

subtopics.title: Collinearity of Points
subtopics.content:
Collinearity of Points

Three points are collinear if they lie on the same line.

Condition: Area of the triangle formed = 0.

questions.question: The coordinates of the origin are:
questions.explanation: The origin is the point where the x-axis and y-axis intersect, and its coordinates are (0,0).

questions.question: The abscissa of (7, –3) is:
questions.explanation: The abscissa is the x-coordinate of a point. For (7, –3), the abscissa is 7.

questions.question: The ordinate of (–5, 4) is:
questions.explanation: The ordinate is the y-coordinate of a point. For (–5, 4), the ordinate is 4.

questions.question: In which quadrant does (–2, –5) lie?
questions.explanation: In Quadrant III, both x and y coordinates are negative. Since (–2, –5) has both coordinates negative, it lies in Quadrant III.

questions.question: The point (0, –4) lies on:
questions.explanation: Any point with x-coordinate 0 lies on the y-axis. Since (0, –4) has x=0, it lies on the y-axis.

questions.question: A point dividing (2, –2) and (8, 10) in ratio 1:2 is:
If A(1,1), B(2,2), C(3,3) → they are:
questions.explanation: All three points lie on the line y=x, so they are collinear.

questions.question: The point equidistant from (2,3) and (–2,3) is:
questions.explanation: Since both points have the same y-coordinate (3), the point equidistant from them will have the same y-coordinate and an x-coordinate that is the average of their x-coordinates: (2 + (–2))/2 = 0. So the point is (0,3).
